subject: Productivity
title: Loss Aversion
description: A micro-lesson that makes Loss Aversion usable.

hook.text: Losing $100 hurts about twice as much as gaining $100 feels good. The brain hates losing.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky proved that humans feel losses roughly twice as strongly as equivalent gains.

discovery.text: This asymmetry explains why people avoid risks even when the expected payoff is positive.

twist.text: Companies exploit loss aversion constantly. Free trials work because canceling feels like losing.

climax.text: Recognizing loss aversion helps you take smarter risks instead of clinging to the safe default.

punchline.text: Fear of loss makes us lose more opportunities.

quiz.question: How strongly do humans feel losses compared to equivalent gains?
